body: @tqchen Could you look into that?

> @jackwish, i want to get my understanding correct, when you say
> 
> > I was looking into PR #3531 and #3512 , and noticed that the PRs are going to support 32 bits quantization.
> 
> are you talking about the inputs or outputs of quantize/dequantize ops being int32? Because, the current implementation for
> 
> 1. Quantize - limits the inputs to be float32 and output to be (u)i8
> 2. Dequantize - The input to be (u)int8 and output to be float32
> 
> Or are you suggesting we should support higher number of bits (>16) for these ops?

@shoubhik I was saying to limit to int8. I know your PR only restricts to int8, while PR #3531 seems trying to enable int8/16/32. I move to here because I saw the two PRs share same code but seems are not consistent in quantization approach. Thanks for helping to clarify that.

> Thanks @jackwish
> This is a very good analysis. Everything makes sense. I upvote for restricting to `(u)int8` for now for `Quantize` and `Dequantize`.
> 
> If in future, we see `(u)int16`, we can tackle then. `int32` is highly unlikely (why not just go to `FP32` as you say).

I am very glad that it helped :)

> > @jackwish, i want to get my understanding correct, when you say
> > > I was looking into PR #3531 and #3512 , and noticed that the PRs are going to support 32 bits quantization.
> >

> > 2. Dequantize - The input to be (u)int8 and output to be float32

> 
> @shoubhik I was saying to limit to int8. I know your PR only your PR restricts to int8, while PR #3531 seems trying to enable int8/16/32. I move to here because I saw the two PRs share same code but seems are not consistent in quantization approach. Thanks for helping to clarify.

Thanks for the explaination.

From the discussion it seems like this implementation follows resize in tensorflow.

However, `resize(align_corners=False)` in tensorflow has bugs since day 1 and it was fixed in Feb this year by introducing a new resize operator in TF. See https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/6720.
The fixed version of align_corners=False agree with pytorch & opencv, etc. It would be good to fix it in topi.
It looks good. Though it has been years that I didnâ€™t check correctness via numerically...why not just compare with PyTorch?

@junrushao1994 the add_grads pr was originally in comparison of PyTorch, but after discussing with @tqchen we agree that it is bad to depend on pytorch (which might also has errors in gradient) for correctness.

@tmoreau89 @vegaluisjose To address the review comments, I have minimized the the auto-generated files, derived `IntelShell` from `VTAShell` and updated pin assignment in `vta_hw.tcl` script. Please take another review.

@kparzysz-quic I have used your PR to try to build runtime. I think we need `tvm_hexagon_remote.idl` and `tvm_hexagon_remote_nd.idl`, which could be located in `fast_rpc` directory , which could let users do it by themself or not. Meanwhile, we lack of `stub.c` / `skel.c` generated by IDL. We can not get the `libtvm_hexagon_remote_stub.so` and `libtvm_hexagon_remote_nd_stub.so` and so on. 

Secondly, we need one procedure in build system  or instruction to tell user to produce `libtvm_hexagon_remote_skel.so ` / `libtvm_hexagon_remote_stub.so`. Like Halide does: https://github.com/halide/Halide/blob/master/src/runtime/hexagon_remote/Makefile

@vinx13 can you get the pool_grad test from the current mode into numerical checking? In the current mode, we essentially copy and paste the grad function into the test function, and compare the two result. If our orginal concept is wrong, what we test against is likely to also be wrong. I think we should slowly replace basically all gradient test with numerical checking ones, and the more complex the grad is, the more crucial this is for us.
Could you also comment on how to encode heterogeneous execution information?
Thank you for the update @liangfu ! I'll reproduce your experiment scripts first before I go ahead with the review.
@vegaluisjose @liangfu @tqchen @liangfu please review, thanks!
@tqchen Let me know if the most recent version is in line with what you requested.
Thanks @lixiaoquan
@liangfu  Looks like the sof compilation succeeded  - one question I have is: does it require Quartus 18.0 or can we rely on the latest version 18.1?

Yeah, I strongly agree with the point that we need to decouple schema reading and the generation.

This is somehow like LLVM's tablegen, which manages repeat and regular codes in a centralized description file to minimize the changes we need to add new IR nodes.

@wweic I feel heterogenous execution will be mainly related to memory management in the VM. We don't need to encode any information in VM for the compilation and codegen. I think we probably need to handle `AllocTensor` a little differently, e.g. making it device aware.
@tmoreau89 I don't think it requires quartus 18.0, it should be applicable on the latest version, although i have not yet tested with 18.1 yet.

Should the match completeness and the fatal stuff be the same PR, though? There are more issues where fatal is involved:
- Ensuring interpreters handle it and testing it
- Ensuring passes that may need to care about it do handle it
Numeral stability would cause trouble when it comes together with randomized inputs, which results in unnecessary flaky tests. Just be careful then :-)

sure

> 'data' in tvm can be composed by the 'boxes' and 'score' in tf/pt.
> valid_counts is to support different ways to generate valid number of boxes, as we have discussed. We don't need score_threshold in this api then.
> The extra argument 'return_indices' is to decide whether to return box indices. I put it right after the input tensor since it is mandatory.
> Other additional arguments make tvm implementation the superset of tf/pt implementation. When converting tf/pt nms, we need to set
> 
> ```
>     force_suppress=True,
>     topk=-1,
>     id_index=0,
>     invalid_to_bottom=False
> ```

Hi, @kevinthesun , I saw you mentioned that when users use tf/pt models with tvm's non_max_suppression op, they can compose 'boxes' and 'score' to generate the 'data' parameter.
Could you give me some hints for how to compose 'boxes' and 'scores'?
This CI build passes this time.
We'll do fatal next time

Why wouldnâ€™t we split this PR into several smaller ones, one for each op/tuning? By the way, static BERT is very ad hoc name imo, which you may not directly understand if you donâ€™t know the limitation of certain system. Shall we try a better name?
Thanks!
Thanks!

@tmoreau89 ,

Would like to address a hot patch in form of PR ?

- It fail with a _very_ tiny limit on newly enabled (kernel > 3) options.
- Probably the mmoization was lost and on new random generated inputs tiny limit is triggered.

Below is the possible fix.

```
--- a/topi/tests/python/test_topi_conv2d_winograd.py
+++ b/topi/tests/python/test_topi_conv2d_winograd.py
@@ -81,7 +81,12 @@ def verify_conv2d_nchw(batch, in_channel, in_size, num_filter, kernel, stride, p
         else:
             func = tvm.build(s, [A, W, C], device, name="relu_%d_%d_%d_%d_%d_%d_%d_%d" % (batch, in_channel, in_size, num_filter, kernel, stride, padding, dilation))
             func(a, w, c)
-        tvm.testing.assert_allclose(c.asnumpy(), c_np, rtol=1e-5)
+
+        rtol = 1e-5
+        if (kernel > 3):
+          rtol = 2e-5
+
+        tvm.testing.assert_allclose(c.asnumpy(), c_np, rtol=rtol)
```
That seems fine, do you mind issuing the PR with the hot fix, and adding myself and @merrymercy to the reviewers? Thanks
Is there a reason why we are disabling cuda tests for now?

> Is there a reason why we are disabling cuda tests for now?

* (kernel_size > 3) was running on cuda only.
* now with this runs on all targeted arch.

(kernel_size > 3) is new for our winograd, since its a larger kernel the accuracy may also drop, interesting that wasn't catched before (i think memoization data was changed).

@tmoreau89 Thank you for the review comments.

> the .qsys and .tcl files still have quite a bit of bulk to them, is there a way to minimize that?

I have already removed unrelated components in the `.qsys` file, it's still large mostly because the detailed settings that related to the HPS configuration (e.g. DDR settings, HPS clocks etc.) is still there. I can try a bit more to figure out whether it can be generated with the help of [qsys_tcl](https://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/programmable/us/en/pdfs/literature/hb/qts/qsys_tcl.pdf) and [ug-qps-platform-designer](https://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/programmable/us/en/pdfs/literature/ug/ug-qps-platform-designer.pdf).

The majority of the `.tcl` file contains pin assignments that related to the chip `5CSEBA6U23I7`. I think I can use for-loops to reduce its size.

> I'm thinking that these auto-generated files could be dropped in the 3rd party dir under intel/de10 to separate what is user generated and what is part of DE10 packaging (files autogenerated by Intel)

Did you mean I can put them at `3rdparty/intel/de10-nano` or `vta/hardware/intel/de10-nano`? (I think we should avoid using the term `de10` instead of `de10-nano`, because of the existence of DE10-Pro and DE10-Lite)

> In order to run Linux on the DE10, where do we find a image to flash the board's SD card? Can you add those instructions to the install.md file as well?

The Linux driver for DE10-Nano and it's related document would be pushed in a separate PR. (See #3394 ) Of course, I can add a brief description about where to download the Linux image, as the user might need them for now.

Thank you @liangfu 

> I can try a bit more to figure out whether it can be generated with the help of qsys_tcl.

That would be great, otherwise see below

> Did you mean I can put them at 3rdparty/intel/de10-nano

That's right - it will keep clean the separation between what's custom code, and what's auto-generated scaffolding code

> Of course, I can add a brief description about where to download the Linux image, as the user might need them for now.

Yes, just adding instructions on flashing the SD card of the DE10Nano to try some examples would be great. Keeping the PRs separated for hardware and driver is fine by me.

The serialization itself doesn't have much to do with quantization. If quantized model needs new opcode in the VM, we need to introduce them first and then extend the serialization/deserialization to support these instructions.
Could we serialize the `dst` in the beginning since it's the most common field? Also could you add the format of every instruciton in the RFC?
Not yet, this just fix the dma request.

@icemelon9 yes, we could, but I am not sure if we want to do that because some instructions don't have it. The current order is consistent to the order that they are constructed but the variable-length filed is rotated to the end.

A quick question here since I can't see this mentioned on #3591 

Is this network going to be quantized per tensor as well as the new per-channel quantization that is appearing in tflite 2.0 ? IIUC, tf1.13 has per tensor quantization rather than the per channel quantization. i.e. more interestingly can the relay design support both ?

https://www.tensorflow.org/lite/performance/quantization_spec?source=post_page---------------------------#per-axis_vs_per-tensor

regards
Ramana

You can feed savedmodel into tf converter as below, relay version is recommended. 
```
from tvm.relay.frontend.tensorflow_parser import TFParser
model_dir = <your savedmodel dir>
graph_def = TFParser(model_dir).parse()
sym, params = relay.frontend.from_tensorflow(graph_def) or nnvm.frontend.from_tensorflow(graph_def)
```
Please use for related questions https://discuss.tvm.ai/:)
cc @nhynes
